links.name: Udacity Three.js Course
description: It is very hard to start with graphics. I myself on multiple occasions
have tried to go through the guides on the internet, but in the end
I ended up getting overwhelmed very quickly by examples they were giving.
There aren't many well organised and well made tutorials on the topic, but
after trying this course out I got a decent foundation, from which I was able
to build up a deeper understanding of graphical programming.

links.name: ShaderToy
description: This is a great website for learning how to write fragment shaders.
Though, it might seem a little daunting at first, writing shaders
that are not linked to the geometry is quite fun. I would say
writing shaders this way is better suited for beginners, since it
rids you of many headaches related to making it work with meshes,
and instead lets you focus on learning shaders themselves.

links.name: Pouet
description: One you get your appetite going, here is the biggest collection
of demo productions. This is a place to go to if you want to be inspired.

links.name: Trauma Demo
description: A ridiculously cool demo that shows just how far some people can
push the possibilities. This whole demo is displayed in text, not
even in pixels, and yet still manages to look ridiculously impressive.

links.name: Ciptunes
description: Those of you that are more interested in music this is an awesome
Soundcloud group that I have been following for a while. They have
a lot of very well produced chiptune music, and if you have never
heard about chiptune this page should do a good job of introducing
you to them.
